meanings.sent1: Mom will outchid you if you don't finish your homework on time.
meanings.sent2: The teacher had to outchid the student for talking during the lesson.
meanings.sent3: The cat seemed to outchid the dog for knocking over the flower vase.
meanings.sent4: The thunderstorm's roar outchid any scolding voice in the room.
meanings.sent5: The principal's outchiding tone echoed through the school halls.

meanings.definition: To surpass in scolding or reprimanding
meanings.sent1: She always manages to outchid her brother when they argue.
meanings.sent2: The strict coach would outchid the players for any mistakes during practice.
meanings.sent3: The outchiding contest between the two parents was quite amusing to watch.
meanings.sent4: Her glare outchid any words she could have spoken in that moment.
meanings.sent5: The outchiding wind drowned out all other sounds in the forest.

meanings.definition: To outdo in scolding or reprimanding
meanings.sent1: He tried to outchid his boss, but it didn't end well for him.
meanings.sent2: The angry customer outchid the manager for the poor service.
meanings.sent3: The outchiding competition at the family dinner was unexpectedly intense.
meanings.sent4: Her outchiding gaze made him feel like a scolded child.
meanings.sent5: The outchiding waterfall of complaints seemed never-ending.
